subject: Re: [junit] Is it Time for JUnit 5
msgSnippet: Jens, Yes, I m really excited about the possibilities of closures in JUnit.  I figure the day after Java 8 is finalized (currently not until September 2013),
messageBody:
Jens,

Yes, I'm really excited about the possibilities of closures in JUnit. I
figure the day after Java 8 is finalized (currently not until September
2013), we'd at least create a branch for exploration. If anyone would want
to organize something based on a pre-release version of Java, (probably by
simply creating a new github repo), please invite me. :-)

David


On Tue, Dec 11, 2012 at 1:33 AM, jens_schauder <jens.schauder@...>wrote:

> **
>
>
> It looks like Closure will finally find their way into Java. With this
> feature many nice ways to do thing become possible. Therefore I am
> wondering if other people agree that it might be time for a JUnit5 putting
> this new feature to good use.
>
> A source for inspiration for me in this regard are the FunSuite of
> ScalaTest http://www.scalatest.org/getting_started_with_fun_suite
>
> There a test definition is a method call (instead of a method definition
> in JUnit) that registers a test for execution. It looks roughly like this:
>
> class MyTestClass{
>
> test("The test name"){
> // the actual test goes here
> }
> }
>
> With this approach things like Rules become extremly trivial, since all
> you have to do is wrap the code block (i.e. closure) in a new new code
> block.
>
> Also parameterized test become fairly easy, because you would just put the
> call to test in a loop.
>
> What do you think? Is this an interesting direction for JUnit to go?
>
> kind regards
> Jens
>
>
